situations.text: 50-year-old Jeff was involved in a medical study for a new medication, designed to lower heart rate and blood pressure amongst those at risk of heart disease. For the first 9 days of April, Jeff was given a placebo (in the form of sugar tablets) and his heart rate (in BPM) was recorded on those days. For the first 9 days of June, Jeff was provided with the actual medication and his heart rate (in BPM) was recorded on those days. The results of the study are depicted in the table below.

questions.text: How much higher was Jeff’s average heart rate (in BPM) for the first 9 days of April than the first 9 days of June?
questions.explanation: Sum of April BPMs / 9 – sum of June BPMs / 9 = 6.7

questions.text: How many days (out of the first 9 days of April) was Jeff’s heart rate 15% greater than his average heart rate for the first 9 days of June?
questions.explanation: Average = Sum of June BPMs / 9 = 7.2; 72 * 1.15 = 82.8; 3 days of 83 or above

questions.text: On the 10th day of April, Jeff’s heart rate was also recorded. As a result of this measurement, his average heart rate for April was 2% higher (than the first 9 days of April). What was Jeff’s heart rate on the 10th day of April?

Suppose that Jeff also took the medication for the first 9 days of August too. The results for August were such that the percentage decrease in his average heart rate for the first 9 days of April compared to June equaled the percentage decrease in his average heart rate for the first 9 days of June compared to August. What was Jeff’s average heart rate for the first 9 days of August?

situations.text: A toy company manufactures and sells two types of toys – termed set A toys and set B toys. Set A toys are designed for children below 12 years of age while set B toys are designed for children aged 12 years or above. For each set A toy sold, the company earns $50 in revenue. For each set B toy sold, the company earns $70 in revenue. Selling these toys is the company’s only source of revenue. The table below summarises the number of toys (set A and set B) sold by the toy company between 2012 and 2018.

questions.text: What was the percentage increase in the number of toys sold (set A and set B) in 2018 compared with 2012?
What percentage of the total revenue generated by the company in 2017 can be attributed to set B toys?
What percentage of the company’s total revenue (from 2012 to 2018) can be attributed to the sale of set A toys?
questions.explanation: (Sum of all set A * 50)/(Sum of all set A * 50 + Sum of all set B * 70) * 100 = 40.3%

questions.text: If the income of the toy store manager is equal to the store’s revenue less tax (35% tax payed on revenue), in what year did the manager generate an income of approximately $29153?

situations.text: The following graph compares the money spent on transportation per year against the household income of families in a particular city. questions.explanation: The less than $5000 bracket spends more than 50% on transport – the others are not even close to this figure

questions.text: Which household income bracket will receive the most money back (for money spent on transportation) from the government?
questions.explanation: The group spending the most money will receive the most money back. Hence, the greater than $50 thousand group is the answer

questions.text: If families did not end up receiving a tax rebate at the end of the year, what percentage more would they pay on transportation than if they had received a tax rebate?

In January 2016, approximately $800,000 was given to the tax office by this company
The company’s profit did not exceed $1,000,000 for the months shown

questions.text: What is the simplified ratio of the volume of water that can be held by container A to the volume of water that can be held by container B?

situations.text: The following table illustrates the number of sales and price per item of the five models of computer sold by a computer store in the month of February. situations.text: The following graph compares the time taken for all customers to be allocated a table at a busy restaurant – on one Friday and Saturday night. Wait times were all between 20 and 45 minutes and were rounded to the nearest 5 minutes.

questions.text: If the ratios of customer waiting times (all between 20 and 45 minutes) were the same on Friday and Sunday and 864 customers went to the restaurant on Sunday, how many customers had to wait 25 minutes or less on Sunday?

situations.text: A random sample of 15 students’ SAT scores (in verbal and math) were recorded and tabulated (as shown below). These scores were subsequently analysed by the test writer.

questions.text: What proportion of math scores was greater than 650 in the sample?

situations.text: Over the year, there are 7 different assessment pieces for chemistry. The assessments each have a different weighting in contributing to the student’s overall score. The results of one student in chemistry is given below.

If the weightage of the exam was halved and quiz 2 tripled, what would be the percentage increase in the student’s overall score?
questions.explanation: Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 1 + Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 2… (using the weightage for the exam as 20 and quiz 2 as 30)= ~80; (80 – 76.6)/76.6 * 100 = 4.4

situations.text: Erin, Lisa, Molly, Joseph and Brian competitively played 3 games of bowling and their scores were recorded. The scores are displayed on the table below. The individual with the highest average score wins the 1st prize of $60, the individual with the second average score wins the 2nd prize of $30 and the individual with the third highest average score wins the 3rd prize of $20.

questions.text: Who won the bowling competition?
questions.explanation: Calculate the averages for each to determine who had the highest average (sum the 3 games and divide by 3) or determine the answer by inspection. Joseph had the highest average of 105

questions.text: How much more money did Lisa win than Brian?
questions.explanation: Lisa came second ($30) and Brian was not in the top 3

questions.text: In the case of a draw for a prize, those who are drawn are required to have another game. Which 2 competitors
questions.explanation: Both Erin and Molly had an average of: (76 + 96 + 120)/3 = 97.3

questions.text: Jill also joins in the competition and achieves the same bowling score in 3 consecutive games. What percentage increase in her 3rd throw will yield a 10% increase in her average score?

situations.text: The following table displays the hours worked per week and the hourly rate of 11 friends. A tax rate of 10% is applied to the first $500 of money generated each week and a tax rate of 20% applies to any money in excess of $500 generated in a week. Whatever is left over after tax is the individual’s income.

questions.text: What was the average number of hours worked per week by the 11 friends?
What was the average amount of money generated (per week) by the 3 individuals with the lowest weekly income?
What average tax rate does Olivia have to pay on her weekly income?
If Penelope and Violet both decided to reduce their number of working hours (per week) by 25%, what would be the effect on the range of incomes of the group of 11 friends (per week)?
questions.explanation: Ralph then becomes the highest earner; 45 * 35 = 1575; 40 * 40 – 1575 = 25; 25 * 0.8 = 20

situations.text: The following table compares the average maximum and minimum temperatures (from January to December 2019) in a city. All temperatures are given in Fahrenheit. To convert from Fahrenheit to degrees Celsius, subtract 32 and multiply by 5/9.

questions.text: What percentage of the 12 months in 2019 had an average minimum temperature below freezing (0 degrees Celsius)?
questions.explanation: 5 months showed an average minimum temperature of below 32F

questions.text: What was the average difference in maximum and minimum temperatures in the city over the 12 months of 2019 (to the nearest degrees Fahrenheit)?

Due to the effects of global warming, the average maximum temperature in January has been increasing by 10% (year-on-year) since 2015. What was the average maximum January temperature from 2015 to 2019 inclusive (in degrees Fahrenheit)?

Suppose that the minimum/maximum temperatures are recorded every day of a month and the values are averaged to give the values in the table above. In February 2019, a minimum temperature of 5 degrees Fahrenheit was recorded on 3 separate occasions. If these 3 minimums were not included in the calculations of an average, how much would the calculated average minimum temperature in February increase by (in degrees Fahrenheit)?

situations.text: The table below compares the number of customer visits and the number of orders placed on cars at a car dealership each month in 2018. To place an order on a car, the customer must visit the car dealership, place an order and pay for the car on the same day as the visit. Each car is sold by the dealership for $5000 and costs the dealership $1170 to source. The dealership’s revenue on each car is the difference between the sale price and the cost associated with sourcing the car. The dealership’s only source of revenue is selling cars.

questions.text: What was the average number of customer visits to the dealership (each month) for 2018?
What was the car dealership’s average monthly revenue for the first quarter of 2018 (i.e from January to March) to the nearest $1000?
In which quarter of 2018 did the car dealership have the highest average monthly revenue?
questions.explanation: The most cars were sold from July to September

questions.text: 30% of the dealership’s monthly revenue is paid to the tax office and the remaining money is paid to the staff. If there were 60 staff members in November 2018 (as opposed to 70 staff members in December 2018) how much more money was paid to each staff member, on average, in November compared to December?

situations.text: Jim started a company that sells computers. The following table compares the number of computer sales each month for the first half of 2018 (by Jim’s company) with 2 different models used to predict the number of computer sales each month (forecast 1 and 2). Jim is trying to decide which model is more accurate in predicting his company’s monthly computer sales.

questions.text: What was the average number of monthly sales for the first half of 2018?
What percentage higher was the average monthly sales prediction for forecast 2 than the average monthly sales prediction for forecast 1?
questions.explanation: ((Sum of forecast 2) – (Sum of forecast 1))/(Sum of forecast 1)

questions.text: In what month was the number of computer sales equal to the average value of forecasts 1 and 2?
questions.explanation: The average of the forecasts equalled: (43 + 35)/2 = 39

questions.text: For July 2018, the sales prediction for forecast 1 was 6% higher than forecast 2.  The actual sales value (for July 2018) was 1% higher than the average of forecast 1 and 2. If the sales prediction for forecast 1 was 1 greater than the actual number of sales, what was the actual number of sales for July (to the nearest whole number)?
questions.explanation: The best way to attempt this is through a trial an error approach of each option to see which leads closest to the prediction for forecast 1 being 1 greater than the actual number of sales

situations.text: The following table compares the number of monthly influenza deaths from 1917 to 1921 in the state of Indiana.

questions.text: What was the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana in 1921?
questions.explanation: Sum of the column/number of entries = 26

questions.text: In which year was the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana the highest?
questions.explanation: Can attempt to calculate the averages or just inspect the data to save time

questions.text: If 500 individuals died immediately (within a day) of contracting influenza in Indiana in 1919 and the immediate death rate remained consistent throughout the year, roughly how many individuals immediately died of influenza in Indiana in the first quarter of 1919?
questions.explanation: 500/total deaths in Indiana in 1919 = 0.17; 0.17 * sum of deaths from Jan – March = 414

questions.text: If the percentage decrease in the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana from 1920 to 1921 equalled that of 1921 to 1922, how many individuals died of influenza per month (on average) in 1922 in Indiana?
questions.explanation: (Average number of influenza deaths in 1920 – average number of influenza deaths in 1921)/(average number of influenza deaths in 1920) * (average number of influenza deaths in 1921) = 3.5

situations.text: A group of individuals (from a variety of different age groups) were asked to choose their favourite leisure activity from a list of 6 different activities. All those surveyed made a selection and the results were tabulated.

questions.text: What was the average number of respondents (per age group above) who chose ‘socialising with 4 or less people’ as their favourite leisure activity?
questions.explanation: Sum of all figures in the row/7 = 214

questions.text: If X teens changed their selection from individual exercise to group exercise, the average number of respondents (per age group above) who chose ‘group exercise/sport’ as their favourite leisure activity would increase by approximately 7.1%. What is the value of X?
questions.explanation: (Total number of respondents who chose ‘group exercise/sport’) * 1.071 – Total number of respondents who chose ‘group exercise/sport’ = 85

questions.text: What leisure activity had the highest average number of respondents per age group?
questions.explanation: Don’t summate each row, just use inspection; tv is TV/videos is the only category with more than 1,000 individuals in an age range

questions.text: Suppose that (on average) 20% of those aged below 50 (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim, while 45% of those aged above 50 (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim. What percentage of respondents (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim?

situations.text: The following 2 tables compare the sales (in millions of Euros) of coffee and bananas in 5 different European countries in 1999 and 2004.

questions.text: If 1 euro is equal to 0.91 pounds, what was the average sales of coffee in the 5 countries in 1999 (in millions of pounds)?
What was the percentage increase in the total number of banana sales in the 5 countries from 1999 to 2004?
questions.explanation: (Total number of banana sales in 2004 - total number of banana sales in 1999)/(total number of banana sales in 1999) * 100 = 186

questions.text: What percentage reduction in the sales of coffee in the UK in 2004 would yield a 20% decrease in the average sales of coffee in the 5 countries in 2004?

In order to increase the sales of coffee in Denmark, the unit price of coffee is reduced by 10%. As a result, the number (not value) of sales of coffee increases by 20% from 2004 to 2005. If the value of sales is equal to the number of sales multiplied by the unit price of coffee, what would be the value of coffee sales in Denmark in 2005?

situations.text: 2 separate surveys were conducted in 1985 and 2011 to determine the average distance travelled per person per year by mode of travel. The results are displayed below.

questions.text: What was the percentage increase in the total distance travelled per person per year from 1985 to 2000?
questions.explanation: (total distance travelled in 2000 – total distance travelled in 1985)/(total distance travelled in 2000) * 100 = 36.6

questions.text: Suppose that all cars require petrol. In 1985 petrol cost $1 per litre while in 2000 petrol cost $1.50 per litre. Each litre of petrol allows a car to travel to travel for 2.5 miles. How much more money was spent on average (per person per year) on petrol (for cars) in 2000 than 1985?
If 1.6km=1 mile and walking for 1km burns 100 calories of energy, how many calories of energy did the average person burn per month (on average) from walking alone in 1985?

Suppose that the ‘other’ modes of travel consist only of boat and tram travel and, on average individuals travel 3 times as much distance on boats than trams (each year). How much more did individuals travel (on average) by boat in 2000 than 1985 (in miles)?

situations.text: The following table illustrates the 6 different types of families within country X and the number/ proportion of people from each family types living in poverty. Assume that every citizen of country X fits into one of those family types and the population of country X is 17 million.

questions.text: On average, out of every 400 citizens of country X, how many are single aged people?
Approximately what percentage of citizens of country X poverty?
If there are 2 million households in country X consisting of couples with children, how many people (on average) occupy each of these households?

Each individual living in poverty from country X claims $300, $400 or $500 weekly from the governments. 40% of those living in poverty claim $500 weekly, while twice as many individuals claim $400 weekly than $300 weekly. How much does country X pay monthly (on average) to each individual living in poverty?

situations.text: The table below depicts the quantities of fruit sold annually (in thousands of tonnes) in 5 different countries.

questions.text: What is the average quantity of peaches sold in each of the 5 countries annually (in tonnes)?
What percentage higher is the average quantity of Cherries sold in each of the 5 countries annually than the average quantity of oranges sold in each of the 5 countries annually?
questions.explanation: (Average of cherries – average of oranges)/(average of cherries) * 100 = 55%

questions.text: If 25% of the ‘others’ category consists of mandarins, how many more mandarins are sold than bananas each month (on average) in Australia?
If each ton of grapes is sold for 36% more than each ton of bananas, what percentage more is generated from the sale of grapes in the UK than bananas in Italy?

situations.text: The number of sales of a product within a number of stores across the cities of America, along with the unit price of the product, are illustrated in the table below.

questions.text: What is the average quantity of the product sold in each of the stores listed?
What would be the percentage increase in the average money generated by these stores from the sale of this product if the unit price was increased by 15%?

If X number more products were sold at both of the Chicago stores, the average money generated by the sale of the products in the Chicago stores would be exactly three-quarters that of the St Louis stores. What is the value of X?
What is the minimum percentage increase required in the unit price of the product in the Seattle stores such that they generate the same money (on average) as the Los Angeles stores?

situations.text: A survey was carried out in a primary school class to determine the number of hours spent watching TV (by students) every week. All students were required to give their answer as a whole number and all responses were between 1 and 10. The number of students are displayed on the y-axis and the number of hours are displayed on the x-axis.

questions.text: How many students watch an average of more than 40 minutes of TV every day?
questions.explanation: 40 * 7/60=4.7; number of students watching 5 or more hours is 30

questions.text: Experts recommend that children watch no more than an average of half an hour of TV daily. How many students in this class are not adhering to this guideline?
questions.explanation: 0.5 * 7 = 3.5; number of students watching 4 or more hours is 30

questions.text: John, Jeff and Jill are in this class. John averages half the time watching TV each day than Jeff while Jeff averages two-thirds the time watching TV each day than Jill. If Jill spends 1 hour watching TV each day (on average), how many classmates spend the same amount of time watching TV (each week to the nearest half hour) as John?
questions.explanation: Jeff – 40 minutes; John – 20 minutes per day = 2 hrs 20 per week; 5 in the 2 hr category

questions.text: What is the average time spent by each student in this class watching TV each week (in hours)?
questions.explanation: Multiply each time by the number of students watching for that time and sum together, then divide by the number of students total

situations.text: Mary is looking to buy a new house. She is researching houses on sale in her desired suburb and taking note of the amenities in each house; in particular, the number of bathrooms in each house. The following table depicts the number of bathrooms and the number of houses (on sale in the suburb) with the indicated number of bathrooms.

questions.text: If the average price of the houses with one bathroom is $250K and the two most expensive houses with one bedroom (each worth $1 million) are sold, by how much will the average house price of the houses with one bathroom decrease (to the nearest thousand dollars)?
What will be the increase in the average number of bathrooms in each of the houses if the number of houses with 3 bathrooms was doubled?
questions.explanation: The final category doesn’t give us a definite number of bathrooms

questions.text: If twice as many of the houses have 5 bathrooms than 7 bathrooms (more than 1), what is the average number of bathrooms in each of the houses?
questions.explanation: Multiply the number of bathrooms by the frequency and add them, divide by the total frequency

questions.text: Mary buys a house for $856K. She takes out a $700K loan and pays $156K from her savings. In order to pay off the loan, Mary plans to pay an average of $51K per year for 14 years. What percentage more would Mary be paying this way in comparison to paying the $856K directly from her savings?

situations.text: The following graph shows the amount of environmental waste created and recycled from 2000 to 2013 in tonnes.

questions.text: What is the closest average of the total waste generated from 2000, 2005 and 2007?
If the total waste generated in 2009 was 3.15 million tonnes, what is the average of total waste generated from 2007-2010?
Which pairs of years had the same average of trashed waste?
In which year was the average of trashed and recycled waste equal to 1.5 million?
questions.explanation: Total waste would be 1.5 * 2 =3; This is seen in 2007

situations.text: The following graph displays the preferred snack choices of students at Hillary’s high school, for both boys and girls.

questions.text: What is the closest average number of boys who preferred snacks starting with a P or V?
Which of the following snack choice has the highest preference numbers as an average of girls and boys?
questions.explanation: The highest of the following is fruit (being ~185); The highest overall would be chips

questions.text: Which snack choice has the lowest preference numbers as an average of boys and girls?
questions.explanation: Vegetable only has an average of ~155; This can be answered via inspection to save time

questions.text: What is the difference between the average number of boys who preferred popcorn and chocolate bars compared to the average number of girls who preferred popcorn and candy, to the closest value?

situations.text: The following graph shows the rates of unemployment for adults in the Nordic countries for men and women. The total population of Denmark is 10 million, Finland is 15 million, Iceland is 20 million, Norway is 25 million and Sweden is 30 million. Assume there are the same number of men and women in each country

questions.text: What is the average unemployment rate amongst men in Denmark and Finland collectively?
What is the average difference between the number of unemployed women and men of the two countries, Denmark and Iceland?
What is the average difference in male and female unemployment rates across all 5 countries?
questions.explanation: Sum of male unemployment rates/5 – sum of female unemployment rates/5 = 0.62

questions.text: If the average unemployment rate was 5% in Norway last year, by how much has the current average unemployment rate for in Norway changed?

situations.text: The following graph shows the number of sneakers sold this month in Chadstone Shopping Centre.

questions.text: What is the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre?

If the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre was 25 sneakers, including a new Bomber sneaker that is not accounted for in the graph, how many Bomber sneakers were sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre?
What is the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre, of those which sold over 15 sneakers?
If the number of New Balance sneakers sold was actually 28, but how much does the average of sneakers sold at Chadstone Shopping Centre change?

situations.text: The following chart displays the trends in overweight and obese people from 1997-2007 in America vs the state of Wisconsin, as a percentage of the total population.

questions.text: If the population of the nation in 2003 and 2001 was 200 million and 150 million respectively, what is the average number of obese people in the nation between 2001 and 2003 on the graph (not including 2002), to the nearest million?
questions.explanation:
200 million * 0.12 = 24 million
150 million * 0.105 = 15.75 million
(24 million + 15.57 million)/2 = 19.875 million = 20 million to the nearest million

questions.text: What is the average number of obese and overweight people combined, between the nation and Wisconsin in 2007, to the nearest ten? The population of the nation in 2007 was 300 million, and in Wisconsin 56 million.
If the average percentage of overweight people in the nation over the years, 1999, 2001, 2003, 2005 and 2007 was 14.78%, what was the percentage of overweight people in the nation in 1999?

If the average number of overweight and obese people in the nation in 2003 and 2007 was 100 million, and there were 150 million overweight and obese people people in the nation in 2003, how many overweight and obese people were in the nation in 2007?

situations.text: The following table shows the transmission of light through a beaker of water with varying salt concentrations over 5 trials.

questions.text: What is the average transmittance across all 5 trials at a salt concentration of 12%, to 2 decimal places?
What is the average difference between the transmittance recordings between trials of the same number at salt concentrations of 6% and 9%?
questions.explanation: Difference of each trial (higher value – lower value) added together and divided by 5 will give 5.2460%

questions.text: If the average transmittance across all salt concentrations for Trial 2 was 100%, what is the transmittance for Trial 2 at a salt concentration of 3%?
questions.explanation: 100 * 5 – the sum of the values of the four other trials = 92.82

questions.text: Which salt concentration out of the following had the lowest average transmittance across Trials 1, 3, 4 and 5?
questions.explanation: You can calculate the average transmittance by summing the trials and dividing the value by 5 for all the different salt concentrations. Or you can attempt to arrive at 9% via inspection

situations.text: The following table below shows the GDP of 5 countries from 1998 to 2003. The values are in billions of dollars.

questions.text: What was average GDP for China from 1998 to 2003, in billions of dollars to the nearest billion?
If the exchange rate from dollars to rupees (Indian currency) is 150 (1 dollar is 150 rupees), what is the average GDP for India between 2001 and 2003 in billions of rupees?
Of these 5 countries, what was the average GDP in 1999?
Of the following years, which year had the lowest average GDP across the 5 countries?
questions.explanation: Can attempt to compare average GDPs for the years by calculating: Sum of column/5; Or, you could seek to answer the this via inspection

situations.text: The following table shows the different prices in dollars and mileage in kilometers for two different models of Chevrolet cars.

questions.text: What is the average price for Corvette models in dollars?
What is the difference between the average mileage of Corvette models and Malibu models?
questions.explanation: Sum of Corvette milages/4 – sum of Malibu milages/4 = 8,910.33

questions.text: If the average price in dollars for Malibu models is $34,676.83, what is the value of the black space in the table, to the nearest dollar?
What is the average mileage between the most expensive Malibu model and the cheapest Corvette model (excluding the blank value)?

situations.text: The table below shows the different times it took for 3 different hamsters to complete a maze designed by some scientists. Each of the hamsters had 10 attempts at completing the maze and all of them completed it.

questions.text: What was the average time taken by hamster 1 to complete the maze in the first 6 trials, rounded to the nearest second?
What was the average time for all 3 hamsters in the 7th attempt?
If a 4th hamster was included in the table, what would its time to complete the maze have been for attempt 4 if the average time for all 4 hamsters on attempt 4 was 37.5 seconds?
What is the difference in the average time taken to the complete the maze across all 10 attempts for hamster 3 and hamster 2?
questions.explanation: Sum of column for hamster 3/10 – sum of column for hamster 2/10  = 3.1; if you get a negative answer, take the magnitude of that as your answer

situations.text: The table below shows the different times it took for 3 different mice to complete a maze designed by some scientists. Each of the mice had 10 attempts at completing the maze and all of them completed it. Some of the values are missing.

questions.text: What was the average time taken to complete the maze on attempt 5 by all 3 mice?
How much longer/shorter did mouse 3 take to complete the maze on the 8th attempt than mouse 2?
If the average time of all 3 mice on attempt 7 is 24, how long did mouse 2 take in attempt 7?
What was the average time of mouse 3 to complete the maze across all its 10 attempts?

situations.text: The following table summarises the minimum rate (per hour) that students must pay to be tutored by poly students, undergraduates, full-time tutors/ graduates and schoolteachers from a tutoring company.  The tutors from this company receive 80% of the rate payed by the student.

questions.text: If a poly student tutors a class of 3 upper primary students for 2 hours, what is the least amount of money that s/he will earn?

What average rate (per hour) were the students charged that day?

Jim (an undergraduate tutor) is saving up for a $5000 car. He tutors a class of 3 lower secondary students for 2 hours every day. A percentage increase of X% in the minimum rate that the tutoring company charges for lower secondary students occurs. As a result of this, it will take Jim 10 fewer days to save up the $5000 for his car. Which of the following is closest to the value of X?

situations.text: The following table illustrates the exchange rate of the USD.

questions.text: Emily wishes to buy a bike worth 450 Australian dollars, what is the value of the bike in US dollars?
Which of the following is closest to the conversion rate of Euros to British pounds?

Suppose that the value of the US dollar increases by 6% but the values of all other currencies remains unchanged. What is the percentage decrease/ increase in the number of American dollars per Japanese Yen?
questions.explanation: Simply a 6% increase as the US dollar increases by 6%

questions.text: An American family decides to move to Canada. The family has allocated 500,000 US dollars for the move and the house. They buy the house for 393,000 Canadian dollars but must pay an extra 6% on stamp duty. The other affiliated costs of making the move amounted to 48,000 US dollars. What percentage of the money allocated for the move and the house remained unspent?

situations.text: Joanne decided to partake in a 35km marathon, which she completed in exactly 7 hours. She went into the marathon with a specific strategy in mind. The following table depicts the cumulative distance (in km) covered by Joanne each hour since the marathon started.

questions.text: Suppose that Joanne stopped for a 15-minute toilet break half an hour into the marathon, what was Joanne’s average running speed for the course of the marathon?
Which of the following best describes Joanne’s marathon strategy?
options: Increasing speed followed by a plateau
questions.explanation: The difference between the cumulative distance each hour is higher at the later times when compared to the earlier

questions.text: If Joanne travelled X km/h faster (on average) in the first hour (but her speeds for the other hours of the marathon remained constant), Joanne could have finished the marathon in ~85.7% of the time. What is the value of X?

questions.text: The first placed participant completed the marathon with an average speed of 10km/ hour. Given that Joanne maintained a constant speed each hour of the marathon (and altered her running speed at the end of each hour), roughly how far away was Joanne from the finish line when the first placed participant crossed the finish line?

situations.text: An experiment was conducted in a chemistry class to determine the effect of temperature on the rate of oxygen gas production (in a chemical reaction). The rate was measured in ml/s. The figure below illustrates the data obtained.

questions.text: What was the average increase in the rate of oxygen gas production per degrees Celsius for temperatures between 30 and 60 degrees Celsius (in ml/s)?

situations.text: The following table illustrates the distance (in miles) between various European cities. Planes regularly fly between these cities and travel in a straight, direct path to the destination.

questions.text: What would an individual have to pay for a 40-mile journey via taxi?

situations.text: The following table compares the number of units of desks sold and shipped from a warehouse to furniture stores across the UK. The transportation of desks has an associated fixed cost of $10,000 and variable costs depending on the number of units purchased.

questions.text: What is the average cost per desk (incorporating the fixed costs into calculations) for 150 desks (in pounds)?
What percentage higher is the average cost per desk (incorporating the fixed costs into calculations) when 100 desks are sold as opposed to 250?
If the above model holds true for sales greater than 250 units, what is the minimum number of desks that need to be purchased such that the average cost per desk is below 125 pounds?
questions.explanation: 10,000 + 100x = 125x; x = 400; Below 125 pounds however; hence, 401 would be the answer

questions.text: One US dollar is equal to 0.83 pounds. A store in the UK buys 50 units of desks from the warehouse. The store then sells a desk to an American customer for 445 US dollars. Considering the average cost of each desk, what percentage profit was made on this sale by the store?

situations.text: Chris is running laps of his oval at school. The circumference of his school’s oval is 0.4 miles. The following table illustrates Chris’ cumulative distance run at various times since he began running. 1 mile = 1.6 km

questions.text: What was Chris’ average speed for his 30-minute run (in km/h)?
For which 5-minute time interval was Chris’ speed (in km/h) the fastest?
options: Can’t tell (as first 5-minute interval isn’t given)
questions.explanation: Most distance travelled (0.8 miles) between minutes 15 and 20

questions.text: Supposing that Chris travels at the same, average, speed for each 5-minute interval but alters his speed every 5 minutes, how many minutes did it take for Chris to run 4 laps of the school oval?

Jerome is also running laps at the same time as Chris but is a slower runner. They both start at the same point on the school oval’s circumference and start running at the same time. However, it takes only 20 minutes for Chris to overlap Jerome. Jerome travels at a constant speed for his entire run. In order to match the distance run by Chris in 30 minutes, how many more minutes does Jerome have to run for than Chris?

situations.text: The following table depicts the tax rate on the taxable income of individual Australians per year. Individuals keep whatever is left after tax has been deducted from taxable income.

questions.text: If an individual earns $163,476 in taxable income for a year, how much of that are they able to keep?
What is the average tax rate (in cents per dollar) for an individual who earns $49923 in taxable income for a year?
For an individual to have an average tax rate of less than 36 cents per dollar, what is the most that they can earn (in taxable income) per quarter/ 3 months (on average)?

If the conversion rate for American dollars to Australian dollars is 1.66. How much taxable income can an individual transfer from America (per year), at most, without having to pay an average tax rate of greater than 20c per $1 (give your answer in American dollars)?

situations.text: Initially, a large fish tank was filled with X gallons of water. Due to a leak in the fish tank, the volume of water in the fish tank gradually decreased at a constant rate. The following table illustrates the volume of water remaining in the fish tank since it was filled.

questions.text: What is the value of X?
After 17 hours, how much water will be remaining in the pool (in gallons)?
Given that the rate of water loss is constant, how long (total) will it take for the fish tank to completely empty?

In order to counter this loss of water, at the 10-hour mark a hose is used to pump water into the fish tank. Water continues to leak at the same rate; however, the house pumps water at a rate of 5 gallons per hour. After how long, since the house was turned on, would the fish tank start to overflow (in minutes)?

situations.text: At a tech company, employees are paid on an hourly basis depending on their employee classification level and the days/ hours they work. Employees’ lunch break is from 1 to 2 O’clock and if they work from 1 to 2, they will be paid extra (delayed meal break).

questions.text: What percentage more does a level 7 employee get paid per hour on a public holiday than a level 3A employee on a weekday (disregarding the potential for a delayed meal break)?
What percentage increase in hourly rate does a delayed meal break result in for a level 5 employee on Sunday?
How much longer will a level 4A employee have to work to generate $2000 than a level 6 employee (given both work only on weekends with normal meal breaks from 1 to 2)?

8 level 3 employees take 4 hours (collectively) to solve an issue at a tech company. Individually, a level 3 employee can solve the issue in 32 hours. How much would the company have to pay 16 level 3 employees to solve the issue (in total) - on a Thursday with normal meal breaks?

situations.text: A traffic light turns from red to green and a car accelerates from rest. The speed of the car in metres per second for the four seconds after the light turned green is illustrated on the graph below.

questions.text: What was the maximum speed (in km/h) reached by the car in the four seconds after the light turned green?
Acceleration is defined as the change in speed per unit of time. What is the average acceleration of the car for the first 2 seconds (in m/s/s)?

After reaching the speed, indicated on the graph, after 4 seconds, the car steadily accelerates – increasing its speed by 10% every second until it reaches the speed limit of 50km/h. How many seconds (from when the lights first turned green) does it take the car to reach 50km/h?

The car travels at an average speed of 45km/h for 10 minutes between the two traffic lights. A motorbike, having started at the same traffic light at the same time as the car, travels at an average speed of 48km/h between the two traffic lights. How much earlier did the motorbike arrive at the second set of traffic lights than the car?

situations.text: George went on a trip from Melbourne to Sydney, making stops along the way for breaks. The distance between Sydney and Melbourne is 350km.

questions.text: What was George’s average speed from Melbourne until his first break?
What was George’s average speed in the first two and a half hours of his journey?
If George travelled at a speed of 30km/h during his detour, how much longer did he spend travelling than if he did not take the detour?
What would have been George’s average speed over the whole journey if he had not taken his break or detoured?

situations.text: An experiment was conducted 6 times to see how far a ball went after being thrown from a slingshot, also measuring the time it took for the ball to touch the ground (assuming the ball stopped when it touched the ground) after being launched from the slingshot.

questions.text: How fast was the ball travelling in the air during the second trial (to 2 decimal places)?
How much faster was the ball in the 5th trial travelling in the air compared to the ball in the 6th trial (to 2 decimal places)?
If the ball in the third trial was travelling in the air at a speed of 33.33 inches/sec, how long did it take for the ball to touch the ground (to 2 decimal places)?
If 1 inch = 3 cm, how fast was the ball in the fourth trial travelling in cm/sec, to the nearest cm?

situations.text: The following table shows the results of an experiment where 6 boys blew a spitball in the classroom to see how far the spitball went and they recorded the time it took to hit the classroom wall. All the boys’ spitballs hit the wall.

questions.text: How fast was the first boy’s spitball travelling, to the nearest millimeter?
If the second boy’s spitball was travelling at a speed of 400cm/sec, how much further did his spitball go compared to the fourth boy’s?
If the average speed of the spitballs of boys 3-6 was 122.32cm/sec, how much time did it take for the 5th boy’s spitball to hit the classroom wall, to 2 decimal places?
Whose spitball travelled the slowest out of all the 6 boys (excluding boy 2 and 5)?
questions.explanation: Boy 1 was the only boy whose spitball travelled less than 100cm/sec

situations.text: There are only 4 trains in Canada, Train 693, 691, 690 and 692. Below are some of the stops as well as the arrival and departure times of those trains from those stops, as well as the days on which the train does not stop at that particular place. All the stops follow in sequential order on the table (ie. the first stop for Train 693 on Monday is Winnipeg, then The Pas… etc, the last being Churchill). If a train does not stop at a place on a particular day, it starts/stops/continues its journey from the next stop.  A route consists of all the stops the train needs to stop at for that day. Unless otherwise specified, trains depart 10 minutes after arrival. The times are in 24-hour time.

questions.text: On Tuesdays, how long does it take for Train 690 to complete its route?
If the distance by rail from Churchill to Gillam is 600km, how fast is Train 692 going on its route on Wednesday?
If John wants to get from Thompson to Winnipeg in the shortest amount of time possible on Tuesday, which train should he take?
questions.explanation: Takes only 5 hrs 15 minutes via train 692 (11:30 to 16:45)

questions.text: If Train 693 travels at a constant speed of 70km/h on its route, how far does it travel on one route (to the nearest km)?
questions.explanation: Time taken for the full route = 39 hours; 39 * 70 = 2730

situations.text: Everyday James goes to school, which is 30km away from his house. On Tuesdays and Wednesdays, he walks to school and runs home from school, but every other day of the week from Monday to Friday he rides his bike to school and back. On weekends he likes to go to his friend Bobby’s house, which is 20km away from his house and 15km away from the school.

questions.text: If he rides his bike at a speed of 15km/h, how long would it take him to go from home to school and back on Thursday?
If he walks at a pace of 8km/h and runs at a speed 1.5 times faster, how long would it take him to get home from school on Wednesday?

James decides it’s taking him too long to get to school by bike, riding at a speed of 20km/h. He decides to carpool with Bobby, but that means he needs to get to Bobby’s house before they leave and ride home from Bobby’s house on the way back. Bobby’s mum drives at 40km/h How much times would James save by doing this on Monday?
If he spends 15 hours a week riding his bike to school, how fast does he ride (assuming he travels at the same speed consistently the whole week)?
